content.description: Up V corner until you can face climb right on thin moves past two horizontal cracks. Easier but bold runout climbing leads to trees.
content.location: 100 ft right of Avoid is a corner crack leading to a gully. The route climbs right on primo granite before the gully.

climbs.name: The Cad
climbs.fa: Bradley White, Bill Hardigan, Tom Bowker and Jay Golden, 1983

content.description: There are two finger jam crack systems on this cliff. Do the system on the right facing the cliff sustained (5-6) with a Short 7+ crux horizontal traverse left. The climb goes directly up, then up to the right, then horizontally left and then up. Make ready for this rope drag by utilizing long slings. One of us pulled the wrong rope and we got the rope stuck. I prussic looped the stuck rope and free climbed the crack to the left at mostly (5-7) with a (5-9) section. I also had a lead rope on putting in gear. This crack is a straight line to the same Rappel root.
content.protection: Lots of stoppers and a couple medium hexes or cams. Cliff ends on a ramp below the roots of trees. Pick a fat root and rappel from it.
content.location: Highest and only section of Noon Peak worth climbing. Pristine granite.

content.description: Climb up to a pine tree then move left to an off width. Up this until you can exit left atop a block then follow a right facing flake/crack to trees.
content.protection: Std rack with a lg cam. My #5 camalot was tipped out. It you have a #6 bring it.
content.location: far left side of this cliff band
